title: Generic Speech Enhancement with Self-Supervised Representation Space Loss
author: Hiroshi Sato (NTT Corporation), Tsubasa Ochiai (NTT Corporation), Marc Delcroix (NTT Corporation), Takafumi Moriya (NTT Corporation), Takanori Ashihara (NTT Corporation), Ryo Masumura (NTT Corporation), ...
relevance_why: The proposed method for speech enhancement and its integration with self-supervised learning models could inform improvements in Haohe Liu's projects on audio generation and enhancement, promoting better performance in audio tasks, including speech restoration and denoising.
background: Enhancing single-channel speech signals by reducing background noise, thereby improving the performance of subsequent tasks such as speech recognition and speaker verification.
contribution: This paper introduces the SSL Mean Square Error (SSL-MSE) loss to solve the challenge of speech enhancement for multiple downstream tasks, achieving improved performance across various speech-related applications.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused on optimizing speech enhancement primarily using traditional metrics like signal-to-distortion ratio (SDR), which did not always translate to better downstream performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon traditional methods by using self-supervised learning features to train the speech enhancement model, focusing on preserving high-level speech information relevant to downstream tasks.

key_innovation: Utilizes a loss function based on self-supervised learning representations to enhance speech signals, aiming to reduce artifacts that could negatively impact subsequent processing tasks.
real_world_impact: This approach could significantly improve communication technologies and automated speech processing systems, making them more robust in real-world noisy environments.

new_terms.self-supervised learning: **Self-supervised learning** is a type of machine learning that uses unlabeled data to generate supervisory signals, allowing models to learn representations without manual labeling.
new_terms.signal-to-distortion ratio (SDR): **Signal-to-distortion ratio (SDR)** is a measure used to evaluate the quality of enhanced signals compared to the original clean signals, focusing on how well distortions are mitigated.
